items.body_markdown:
Note:- I'm not talking about Increment & Decrement Operator. I'm talking about prefix & postfix expressions.

Example in python:-
```
def calculate(a, b, c, d):
    return a * ( b + c ) / d 

calculate(1,2,3,4)

```
I know that python doesn't support prefix or postfix expressions. But imagine if python supports postfix expression, I can write the function like this
```
def calculate(a, b, c, d):
    return a b c + * d /

calculate(1,2,3,4)
```

I read in this [link][1] that evaluating the postfix expressions are faster than infix expressions
1. The time required for evaluating an infix expression is O(n^2) -> reason - Need to find the operators having the highest precedence.
2. The time required for evaluation of postfix expression is O(n) -> reason - No need to find the precedence of operators. We just need to evaluate from left to write

If this is the case then why popular programming languages like c, c++, java, python, ruby, PHP doesn't support postfix expressions natively?


  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/60464062/8496480
items.title: Does any Programming language support Postfix(Reverse Polish Notation) or Prefix expressions?

comments.body_markdown: A few things: never swallow exceptions. Remove the empty `catch` block and declare your methods as `throws Exception`. That way you can actually get an error to point you in the right direction. Follow Java coding conventions and indent your code to make it easier to understand. Include the `import` statements in your question, we need a [mcve] if possible. That may include your .wav file. Side note: it probably has nothing to do with your IDE, but you may need to put the dependencies in place manually. See also [ask].
comments.body: A few things: never swallow exceptions. Remove the empty catch block and declare your methods as throws Exception. That way you can actually get an error to point you in the right direction. Follow Java coding conventions and indent your code to make it easier to understand. Include the import statements in your question, we need a minimal reproducible example if possible. That may include your .wav file. Side note: it probably has nothing to do with your IDE, but you may need to put the dependencies in place manually. See also How to Ask.

answers.body_markdown: I think you over-killed. first, using a hashset can lead to O(N) algorithm, which you have to avoid sort (O(NlogN)). But due to large memory footprint, I'd rather go with a sort and it is practically faster. Second, if you choose a sort of A, then a simple for-loop with detect any gap in the positive part of the array, which is now your result. You should avoid Hashset and the many loops in your code

comments.body_markdown: Why the ACKs? TCP already does that itself. If your messages don't arrive you will find out via exceptions or timeouts. Adding your own ACKs is just complicating your life for no benefit. 10ms is far too short for a read timeout, and a `readLine()` call that doesn't store and test the result is pointlessly throwing away data.
comments.body: Why the ACKs? TCP already does that itself. If your messages don't arrive you will find out via exceptions or timeouts. Adding your own ACKs is just complicating your life for no benefit. 10ms is far too short for a read timeout, and a readLine() call that doesn't store and test the result is pointlessly throwing away data.

comments.body_markdown: I understand that there is a degree of redundancy with the "ACK". The person requesting the code wanted each message to include an acknowledgement. You are probably right that it would be valid to remove these operations. As for the "pointlessly throwing away data", the reason is that IF there is data at this stage, it is pointless/erroneous and needs to be discarded.
comments.body: I understand that there is a degree of redundancy with the "ACK". The person requesting the code wanted each message to include an acknowledgement. You are probably right that it would be valid to remove these operations. As for the "pointlessly throwing away data", the reason is that IF there is data at this stage, it is pointless/erroneous and needs to be discarded.

comments.body_markdown: Note that you have a single instance of the following variables `intBufferSize`, `shortAudioData`, `audioTrack`, so when you push one key it will start the thread loop and set the autio track for example, but when you push the next key it will start another thread loop and overwrite the previous audio track while it is still playing. Consider moving the previously mentioned variables inside the `threadLoop` method.
comments.body: Note that you have a single instance of the following variables intBufferSize, shortAudioData, audioTrack, so when you push one key it will start the thread loop and set the autio track for example, but when you push the next key it will start another thread loop and overwrite the previous audio track while it is still playing. Consider moving the previously mentioned variables inside the threadLoop method.

comments.body_markdown: Also, you have a single `audioThread`, but every key press tries to start the thread again, this will not work how you intend it to. You either need to make a brand new thread each time a key is pressed, or you need to use a single thread to manage a list of sounds/keys to play etc.
comments.body: Also, you have a single audioThread, but every key press tries to start the thread again, this will not work how you intend it to. You either need to make a brand new thread each time a key is pressed, or you need to use a single thread to manage a list of sounds/keys to play etc.

comments.body_markdown: Generally speaking the term "durable" in messaging has a pre-existing meaning. A "durable" message is one that "will survive a restart." What you're talking about is more like a non-destructive queue where acknowledgements don't actually remove messages. This is an advanced use-case not likely supported by Spring's internal STOMP broker. However, it would be supported by an external broker like ActiveMQ Artemis.
comments.body: Generally speaking the term "durable" in messaging has a pre-existing meaning. A "durable" message is one that "will survive a restart." What you're talking about is more like a non-destructive queue where acknowledgements don't actually remove messages. This is an advanced use-case not likely supported by Spring's internal STOMP broker. However, it would be supported by an external broker like ActiveMQ Artemis.

items.title: When using Spring Boot and STOMP, is there a way to make queues durable?

comments.body_markdown: Need to be careful to transform to something that maybe can have duplicate keys ... using your analogy you might have to put this into the map "Melbourne" : "Australia", "Melbourne" : "England", "Melbourne" : "North America" [3 of these IOWA, Arkansas, and Florida].
comments.body: Need to be careful to transform to something that maybe can have duplicate keys ... using your analogy you might have to put this into the map "Melbourne" : "Australia", "Melbourne" : "England", "Melbourne" : "North America" [3 of these IOWA, Arkansas, and Florida].

comments.body_markdown: I don't believe you'll find an elegant solution using `stream()` alone as you need to account for the duplicate keys/values. Iterating the maps may be the best option, though I could be wrong.
comments.body: I don't believe you'll find an elegant solution using stream() alone as you need to account for the duplicate keys/values. Iterating the maps may be the best option, though I could be wrong.

comments.body_markdown: @Zephyr There's `Collectors.groupingBy` that will handle the duplicates automatically.
comments.body: @Zephyr There's Collectors.groupingBy that will handle the duplicates automatically.

answers.body_markdown:
You can do it like this.

The data
```
Map<String, List<String>> map = Map.of("North America",
		List.of("New York", "Vancouver", "Paris"), "Europe",
		List.of("London", "Paris"));
```
The process
- stream the `entrySet`
- `flatMap` the list and map to an array
- then build the new map with the results of the array.
- I added a merge function to handle duplicate keys in case a city is in two countries.
```

Map<String, String> result = map.entrySet().stream()
		.flatMap(e -> e.getValue().stream()
				.map(str -> new String[] { str, e.getKey() }))
		.collect(Collectors.toMap(a -> a[0], a -> a[1],
				(countries, country)->countries + ", " + country,
				HashMap::new));

result.entrySet().forEach(System.out::println);
```
prints
```
New York=North America
Vancouver=North America
London=Europe
Paris=Europe, North America
```
Instead of using string concatenation to handle duplicates you could also do this using a `Map<String,List<String>>` to handle duplicate cities.
